variant.question: The induced drag of an aeroplane:

options.text: The maximum angle of climb would be achieved at speed C.

may not exceed 90% of the PCN.

For normal utility and aerobatic category aeroplanes, the speed at 15 m (50 ft) above the take-off surface level must not be less than –(2)
For single-engine aeroplanes, the higher of –(i) A speed that is shown to be safe under all reasonably expected conditions, including turbulence and complete engine failure; or (ii) ...
How is V~2~ affected if T/O flaps 20° is chosen instead of T/O flaps 10°?

options.text: V~2~ decreases if not restricted by V~MCA~.
V~2~ increases in proportion to the angle at which the flaps are set.
V~2~ has the same value in both cases.
V~2~ has no connection with T/O flap setting, as it is a function of runway length only.

variant.question: How is V~2~ affected if T/O flaps 20° is chosen instead of T/O flaps 10°?

options.text: V2 decreases if not restricted by VMCA.
V2 has no connection with T/O flap setting, as it is a function of runway length only.
V2 has the same value in both cases.
V2 increases in proportion to the angle at which the flaps are set.

variant.question: Take-off run is defined as the:

options.text: horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the take-off to a point equidistant between the point at which V~LOF~ is reached and the point at which the aeroplane is 35 ft above the take-off surface.
distance to 35 feet with an engine failure at V~1~ or 115% all engine distance to 35 feet.
distance from brake release to V~2~.
distance to V~1~ and stop, assuming an engine failure at V~1~.

variant.question: Take-off run is defined as the:

options.text: horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the take-off to a point equidistant between the point at which VLOF is reached and the point at which the aeroplane is 35 ft above the take-off surface.
distance to V1 and stop, assuming an engine failure at V1.
distance to 35 feet with an engine failure at V1 or 115% all engine distance to 35 feet.
distance from brake release to V2.

variant.question: Minimum V~2~ speed (V~2MIN~) is limited by both the stall speed (V~SR~) and minimum control speed (V~MC~). Which statement is correct?

options.text: At high-density altitudes and high weight, V~2MIN~ is often limited by the stall reference speed (V~SR~).
V~2MIN~ is calculated with all engines operating, for flight with one engine inoperative, another safety speed must be used.
V~2MIN~ cannot be lower than the highest of 1.05 times V~MC~ and 1.2 times V~SR~.
At high-density altitudes and high weight, V~2MIN~ is often limited by the speed for minimum control (V~MC~).

variant.question: Minimum V~2 ~speed (V~2~~min~) is limited by both the stall speed (V~sr~) and minimum control speed (V~mc~). Which statement is correct?

options.text: At low-density and high weight, V2min is often limited by the stall reference speed (VSR)
V2min cannot be lower than the highest of 1.05 times VMCA and 1.2 times VSR
V2min is calculated with all engines operating, for flight with one engine inoperative, another safety speed must be used.
At low-density altitudes and high weight, V2min is often limited by the speed for minimum control (VMC).

variant.question: An aborted take-off procedure on a dry runway with all engines operating or with an engine failure incorporates a so-called accelerate stop distance (ASD). In case of an engine failure, the ASD is calculated by adding the sum of the required distance to accelerate to the engine failure speed (V~EF~), the distance to accelerate to the highest speed reached during the rejected take-off,...

options.text: the distance to come to a full stop, and a distance equivalent to two seconds at V1
the distance to come to a full stop, and a distance equivalent to two seconds at V1, all multiplied by a factor of 1.15.
150 % of the distance to come to a full stop, and a distance equivalent to two seconds at VEF.
and the distance to come to a full stop multiplied by 1.15.

In accordance with EASA CS 25 the take-off safety speed V~2 MIN~ for turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes with more than three engines may not be less than:

According to CS-25, there may be NO buffeting condition in normal flight, including configuration changes during the cruise, severe enough to interfere with the control of the aeroplane, to cause excessive fatigue to the crew, or to cause structural damage. Stall warning buffeting within these limits is allowable. There may be NO perceptible buffeting condition in the cruise configuration in straight flight at any speed up to VMO/MMO (except the stall warning buffeting). Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: High-speed buffet may occur at speeds around VMO/MMO during manoeuvres away from straight flight.
When buffet becomes noticeable, it will probably be so severe that the pilot will NOT be able to read the instruments or to control the aeroplane.
NO high-speed buffet will occur at any speed up to VMO/MMO, unless the aeroplane is approaching the stall.
The aeroplane has entered an undesired state if high-speed buffet becomes perceptible and recovery from this may be impossible.

At its landing mass, and on rigid pavement, the aircraft ACN is equal to 50. Which runway, associated with the PCN reported, is suitable for landing?
The reference stalling speed of a twin-engined turbo-jet aeroplane is 100kt in the landing configuration. VMCL is 128KT. The minimum speed a pilot must maintain on short finals is:

ICAO Annex 14 describes the principles of pavement classificatlon numbers (PCNs) and aircraft classification numbers (ACNs). These numbers describe the strength of a surface and the impact an aircraft will have on a surface. Which option is correct?

options.text: An aircraft with a given ACN value may operate on a surface with a lower PCN value if certain operational limitations are met.
The published PCN value must be equal to or lower than the aircraft's ACN value to allow for continuous and unlimited operation.
The PCN value must be exactly equal to the ACN value of an aircraft in order to allow for unrestricted operation of that aircraft.
The ACN of an aircraft is independent of the actual weight of the aircraft and tyre pressure and is always reported for maximum weight.
